Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Minimally invasive biosensors for detecting flavivirus infection
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Public health experts are concerned that Zika virus may soon be spread by mosquitoes in the continental United States. The goal of this project is to understand if patches that contain small nozzles (known as "microneedles") can detect infection by Zika virus. This technology may allow healthcare providers to improve management and treatment of patients who present with Zika-like symptoms.

This project involves creating electrodes that can detect components of the Zika virus. These electrodes will be combined with microneedles to create inexpensive, painless, and portable patches. The program will examine the functionality of the microneedle-containing patches with Zika component-containing blood and skin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transdermal biosensing has become more common in recent years. Microneedles (minature versions of hypodermic needles) may be used for minimally invasive detection of analytes in body tissues. This program advanced both the technologies for making microneedles and the approaches for detecting analytes in body tissues.

For example, astudy with Sandia National Labs showed that hollow metal microneedle arrays could be created using a combination of two photon polymerization, micromolding, and electroplating methods. A solid microneedle with a ledge was created with two photon polymerization and  molded with polydimethylsiloxane. The mold was coated with a seed layer of sold-titanium and electroplated with pulsed deposition to create a hollow microneedle. The hollow microneedle arrays were flexible, able to penetrate porcine skin, and capable of injecting a trypan blue dye into porcine skin. 

In another study with the University of Adelaide, a 3D-printed micro-needle was combined with an optical fiber tip sensor to produce an in vivo biosensor for reversible prtein carbonylation (a marker of redox balance in living systems). In vivo measurements of protein carbonylation were performed in porcine tissue and murine tissue. The sensor showed a detectable and relatively steady concentration of analyte in the subcutaneous space under the skin.

In another study with the Indian Institute of Technology in Varanasi, a solid-state ion sensor in a two-electrode configuration was itegrated with a hollow microneedle  for transdermal sensing of potassium ion levels. The all solid-state microneedle assembled potentiometric sensor included a PVC matrix membrane ion sensing layer over a non-specific ion carrier impregnated membrane, which was made from a suspension of  siloxane-polyindole-gold nanoparticles to maintain a constant dipolar potential during potentiometric transdermal sensing. The reference electrode was an Ag/AgCl electrode covered with a p-toluene-sulfonate impregated polyndole-gold nanoparticle-organically modified silicate membrane.

The optical and potentiometric detection mechanisms described above will be expanded to cover many types of analytes, including metabolites created by the body in health and illness as well as pathogenic organisms (e.g., viruses and bacteria).
